questions.question: What is the most common cause of cell injury?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Hypoxia Explanation: Hypoxia is the most common cause of cell injury. The mechanism of hypoxic cell injury is reduced oxidative respiration. The most common cause of hypoxia is ischemia. Causes of cell injury include: Hypoxia Physical agents Chemical agents and drugs Infectious agents Immunologic reactions Genetic abnormalities Nutritional imbalances Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th edition, Page 39

questions.question: Identify the correct combination of most and least sensitive cells to hypoxia.

options.A: Most sensitive - hepatocytes and least sensitive - Lymphocytes
options.B: Most sensitive - bone marrow cells and least sensitive - nerve cells
options.C: Most sensitive - retina and least sensitive - adipose tissue
options.D: Most sensitive - neurons and least sensitive - fibroblasts

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Most sensitive - neurons and least sensitive - fibroblasts Explanation: The cells most sensitive to hypoxia are neurons and the least sensitive are fibroblasts. CA1 Neurons of the hippocampus are the most sensitive to hypoxia. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 37

questions.question: Which among the following is not a feature of reversible cell injury?

options.A: Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria
options.D: Detachment of ribosomes from granular ER

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Large Amorphous densities. Explanation: Large amorphous densities are seen in the mitochondria in irreversible cell injury . The following changes occur in reversible cell injury: Cellular swelling: Earliest change ATP depletion leads to sodium-potassium pump failure Na and water accumulate within the cell, causing cellular swelling Fatty change: Seen in cells involved in or dependent on fat metabolism (liver hepatocytes and myocardial cells) Ultrastructural findings: Mitochondrial swelling and small amorphous densities Plasma membrane blebs Swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Detachment of ribosomes from granular ER (Decreased protein synthesis and increased fatty changes). Nuclear changes like disaggregation of granular and fibrillar filaments. Myelin figures. Myelin figures: These are derived from the membranes of the cell. These are concentric lamellations which are made up of phospholipids and calcium. Myelin figures are seen in both reversible and irreversible cell injury. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 37

questions.question: Match the following descriptions of the nuclear changes in irreversible cell injury. I. Pyknosis a. Nuclear fragmentation II. Karyorrhexis b. Dissolution of nucleus III. Karyolysis c. Shrinking of the nucleus and clumping of nuclear chromatin
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) I-c, II-a, III-b Explanation: The nuclear changes seen in irreversible cell injury are as follows: Pyknosis Shrinking of the nucleus and clumping of nuclear chromatin Karyorrhexis Nuclear fragmentation Karyolysis Dissolution of nucleus Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, Page 40

questions.question: Which of the following is the most important electron microscopic finding in irreversible cell injury?

options.A: Small amorphous densities in the mitochondria
options.C: Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria
options.D: Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria Explanation: Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria are the most important electron microscopic finding in irreversible cell injury. It occurs due to an increased calcium influx in the mitochondria. The findings can be observed only in electron microscopy. Irreversible cell injury: Defining features: Severe membrane damage. Severe mitochondrial damage leads to the formation of large, flocculant, amorphous densities due to increased calcium influx. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 38-40

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding free radical injury is true? functions. strand breaks.

options.A: Free radicals are highly stable molecules with unpaired electrons that contribute positively to cellular
options.B: Free radical injury can lead to cell damage through lipid peroxidation, protein oxidation, and DNA
options.C: Antioxidants play a minor role in protecting cells from free radical damage.
options.D: Free radicals primarily cause cell death through apoptosis and do not contribute to necrosis.

questions.explanation: oxidation, and DNA strand breaks. Correct answer: B) Free radical injury can lead to cell damage through lipid peroxidation, protein oxidation, and DNA strand breaks. Explanation: Free radical injury can indeed lead to cell damage through processes such as lipid peroxidation (which damages cell membranes), protein oxidation (which affects enzyme function and structural integrity), and DNA strand breaks (which can lead to mutations). Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Pages 67, 68

questions.question: A sample of tissue preparation is subjected to oxidative stress under experimental conditions. Different types of free radicals are generated in the process. However, the researcher wants to work on the most potent and reactive free radicals among the ones generated. Which of the following will he be working on?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Hydroxyl radical. Explanation: The hydroxyl radical (OH•) is considered the most potent and reactive free radical due to its high reactivity and ability to quickly react with cellular components, leading to oxidative damage. Hydroxyl radicals are primarily formed through the Fenton reaction, which involves the interaction of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) with transition metal ions such as iron (Fe) or copper (Cu). Another source of hydroxyl radicals is the Haber-Weiss reaction, which occurs in the presence of superoxide radicals (O2-) and hydrogen peroxide. Antioxidants: Non-Enzymatic Enzymatic Vitamin E, A, and C. (Vitamin A is not an antioxidant in the aqueous humor of eye. Se, Mn, Zn. Superoxide dismutase. Catalase. Glutathione peroxidase. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 67,68

questions.question: Which of the following is a telltale sign of free radical injury in cells?

options.A: Increased antioxidant levels in the cell
options.C: Generation of Lipofuscin and stress markers such as malondialdehyde (MDA)

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Generation of Lipofuscin and stress markers such as malondialdehyde (MDA). such as malondialdehyde (MDA) and the generation of Lipofuscin. These are the tell-tale signs of free radical injury. On ageing, atrophy of organs occur, causing free radical injury. Lipofuscin gets deposited on this, hence it is responsible for brown atrophy of liver and heart. HPE: Perinuclear brown pigment. Special stain: Oil red - 0. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Pages 67,68

questions.question: What is the primary function of superoxide dismutase (SOD) in cells?

options.C: Neutralization of superoxide anion radicals (O2•-) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)

questions.explanation: (H2O2) Correct answer: C) Neutralization of superoxide anion radicals (O2•-) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) Explanation: Superoxide dismutase (SOD) is an important enzyme found in cells that plays a crucial role in antioxidant defence mechanisms. Its primary function is to catalyze the conversion of superoxide radicals (O2•-) into oxygen (O2) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). SOD is classified into different types based on its metal cofactor, such as Copper/zinc SOD (Cu/Zn SOD) found in the cytoplasm Manganese SOD (Mn-SOD) in the mitochondria Extracellular SOD (EC-SOD) located outside the cell. Antioxidants: Non-Enzymatic Enzymatic Vitamin E, A, and C. (Vitamin A is not an antioxidant in the aqueous humor of eye. Se, Mn, Zn. Superoxide dismutase. Catalase. Glutathione peroxidase. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 67, 68

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and muscle atrophy, primarily affecting his arms and legs. He reports difficulty with tasks such as buttoning shirts and lifting objects. On examination, you note fasciculations in his upper extremities and decreased muscle strength. His reflexes are brisk, and there is no sensory deficit. Nerve conduction studies show signs of denervation. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the SOD1 gene. Based on this clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) Explanation The SOD1 gene encodes for the enzyme superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), which plays a crucial role in protecting cells (Brain) from oxidative stress. Mutations in the SOD1 gene are associated with familial cases of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness, atrophy, and eventually paralysis. Mutant forms of SOD1 can have toxic effects on neurons. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 67, 68

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the primary function of chaperones within the cellular environment?

options.A: Facilitating the degradation of misfolded proteins
options.B: Promoting protein folding and preventing misfolding
options.C: Catalyzing enzymatic reactions by providing a scaffold

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Promoting protein folding and preventing misfolding Explanation: Chaperones in the ER are responsible for properly folding newly synthesized proteins, and misfolded polypeptides are shuttled into the cytoplasm where they are ubiquitinated and targeted for proteolysis in proteasomes. If unfolded or misfolded proteins accumulate in the ER, they trigger the unfolded protein response. The unfolded protein response activates signalling pathways that increase the production of chaperones, enhance proteasomal degradation of abnormal proteins, and slow protein translation, thus reducing a load of misfolded proteins in the cell. Disease Misfolded protein Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease Prions Cystic fibrosis Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) Facilitating the degradation of misfolded proteins (Option A): proteasome degrades misfolded or damaged proteins that have been tagged with ubiquitin. This ensures protein quality control and prevents toxic protein accumulation in the cell. Catalyzing enzymatic reactions by providing a scaffold (Option C): Enzymes accelerate biochemical reactions by stabilizing the transition state and providing an active site, a structural scaffold where substrates can interact efficiently. Transporting proteins across cellular membranes (Option D): Translocons are membrane-embedded channels that facilitate the movement of proteins across or into membranes, such as into the endoplasmic reticulum or mitochondria. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 54

questions.question: Which of the following pathways are responsible for the pathogenesis of ALS?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Ubiquitin-proteasome pathway Explanation: The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is primarily responsible for the degradation of misfolded proteins within the cell. In this pathway, misfolded or damaged proteins are tagged with ubiquitin molecules, which target them for degradation by the proteasome, a large multi-subunit protein complex. Dysfunction of the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway can lead to the accumulation of misfolded proteins and contribute to the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Parkinson's disease. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22033150/
